title: Paracetamol (Acetaminophen)
content: Paracetamol is a common painkiller used to treat aches and pain. It can also reduce fever. It's available over the counter and is safe when taken correctly. Always follow dosage instructions carefully.

dosage_info.note: Consult pharmacist or doctor for children's dosing

side_effects: Allergic reactions (rare) - rash, swelling, breathing difficulty
Liver damage with overdose or prolonged high doses
contraindications: Severe liver disease or liver failure
warnings: Do not exceed maximum daily dose (4g/day)
Avoid or limit alcohol while taking
Check other medications for paracetamol content (many cold/flu products contain it)
Caution with liver disease - consult doctor
Caution with kidney disease - consult doctor
drug_interactions: Warfarin (blood thinner) - may increase bleeding risk with regular use
Other paracetamol-containing products - risk of overdose
overdose_warning: Paracetamol overdose is serious and can cause liver failure. Seek immediate medical attention if overdose suspected, even if feeling well.
safety_disclaimer: Always consult a pharmacist or doctor before use if you have existing health conditions or take other medications.

title: Ibuprofen
content: Ibuprofen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It reduces inflammation and pain, and can also reduce fever. Available over the counter for short-term use. Should be taken with food.

dosage_info.max_daily: Maximum 1200mg daily for OTC use (higher doses require prescription)
dosage_info.note: Always take with or after food

side_effects: Increased risk of stomach ulcers (long-term use)
contraindications: Known allergy to ibuprofen or other NSAIDs
History of stomach ulcers or GI bleeding
warnings: ALWAYS take with food to reduce stomach upset
Not suitable for people with stomach ulcers
Caution with asthma - may trigger symptoms
Caution with kidney, heart, or liver problems
Avoid in late pregnancy (after 30 weeks)
May interact with blood thinners
Use lowest effective dose for shortest time
drug_interactions: Warfarin and other blood thinners - increased bleeding risk
Aspirin - reduced aspirin effectiveness, increased GI risk
Blood pressure medications - may reduce effectiveness
safety_disclaimer: Consult doctor before use if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, kidney disease, or are over 65. Not recommended for long-term use without medical supervision.

title: Aspirin (Acetylsalicylic Acid)
content: Aspirin is used to reduce pain, fever, and inflammation. Low-dose aspirin is also used to prevent heart attacks and strokes in high-risk individuals, but should only be used for this purpose under doctor supervision.
uses: Heart attack and stroke prevention (low dose, doctor prescribed only)
contraindications: Active stomach ulcer or GI bleeding
warnings: NEVER give to children under 16 (risk of Reye's syndrome)
Avoid with stomach ulcers or history of GI bleeding
Caution with asthma - may trigger attacks
Stop 7 days before surgery unless doctor advises otherwise
May interact with blood thinners
Do NOT start daily aspirin for heart without doctor advice
drug_interactions: Warfarin and other blood thinners - significantly increased bleeding risk
Other NSAIDs - increased GI and bleeding risk
emergency_use_note: During a suspected heart attack, emergency services may advise chewing 300mg aspirin. Do NOT do this on your own - wait for medical advice as aspirin can be dangerous for some people (allergies, bleeding disorders, ulcers).
safety_disclaimer: Do not start daily aspirin therapy without consulting your doctor. The risks may outweigh benefits for some people.

title: Antihistamines
content: Antihistamines are medications that help relieve allergy symptoms by blocking histamine. They can be sedating (drowsy) or non-sedating types. Choose based on your needs and read labels carefully.

dosage_info.note: Varies by specific medication - always read product label
dosage_info.general: Most non-drowsy types taken once daily

contraindications: Known allergy to the specific antihistamine
Certain types contraindicated with prostate problems
Some not suitable for children under certain ages
warnings: Sedating types may impair driving - do not drive if drowsy
Avoid alcohol with drowsy antihistamines
Caution with glaucoma, enlarged prostate
Some not suitable for children - check age restrictions
May interact with other sedating medications
safety_disclaimer: Choose non-drowsy types if you need to drive or operate machinery. Consult pharmacist for appropriate choice.

title: Antacids
content: Antacids are medications that neutralize stomach acid. They provide quick relief for heartburn, acid reflux, and indigestion. For frequent symptoms, consult a doctor as this may indicate an underlying condition.

dosage_info.timing: Usually taken when symptoms occur or after meals

warnings: May affect absorption of other medications - take 1-2 hours apart
Not for long-term regular use without doctor advice
Kidney disease: avoid magnesium types
High blood pressure: avoid high sodium types
Frequent heartburn (more than twice a week) needs doctor evaluation
drug_interactions: May reduce absorption of many medications including antibiotics
Always separate antacids from other medications by 1-2 hours
safety_disclaimer: Occasional use is generally safe. See doctor if you need antacids regularly, as this may indicate a condition requiring different treatment.

title: Cough Medicines
content: Cough medicines can help relieve coughing symptoms. There are two main types: expectorants (help bring up mucus) and suppressants (reduce the urge to cough). Evidence for effectiveness is limited; honey may be equally effective for cough.

dosage_info.note: Follow product label - varies by product
dosage_info.general: Usually taken every 4-6 hours as needed
dosage_info.honey_alternative: Honey (1-2 teaspoons) can be as effective for adults/children over 1

contraindications: Children under 6 - most cough medicines not recommended
Children under 12 - some products not suitable
Chronic respiratory conditions - consult doctor first
warnings: Don't suppress a productive cough unnecessarily
Not recommended for children under 6
Check for alcohol content
Many products contain multiple ingredients - check for duplications
May interact with other medications
drug_interactions: SSRIs - serotonin syndrome risk with dextromethorphan
safety_disclaimer: Cough lasting more than 3 weeks needs medical evaluation. Do not use cough suppressants if you have chronic lung conditions without doctor advice.

title: Decongestants
content: Decongestants reduce nasal congestion by narrowing blood vessels in the nasal passages. Available as oral tablets or nasal sprays. Nasal sprays should not be used for more than 7 days.

types.nasal_sprays: Oxymetazoline, Xylometazoline - local effect, faster acting

dosage_info.oral: Follow product label - usually every 4-6 hours
dosage_info.nasal_spray: 1-2 sprays per nostril, maximum 2-3 times daily

side_effects: Rebound congestion (nasal sprays with prolonged use)
contraindications: Within 14 days of MAO inhibitor use
warnings: NOT suitable for people with high blood pressure or heart disease
Avoid if taking MAO inhibitors
Nasal sprays: use MAXIMUM 7 days to avoid rebound congestion
May cause difficulty sleeping - take earlier in day
Caution with diabetes, thyroid problems, glaucoma
May affect athletic drug testing
drug_interactions: MAO inhibitors - dangerous blood pressure increase
Blood pressure medications - may reduce effectiveness
rebound_warning: Using nasal spray decongestants for more than 7 days can cause 'rebound congestion' - your nose becomes more blocked when you stop using them.
safety_disclaimer: Not suitable for everyone. People with heart conditions or high blood pressure should consult doctor before use.
